videos.title: Dror Yikra | Barry and Batya Segal Music
videos.description:
Traditional Yemenite Folk Song. Lyrics by Dunash Ibn Labrat.

Experience the timeless beauty of "Dror Yikra," one of the most cherished Shabbat songs across Jewish communities for generations. In this captivating performance, Barry and Batya Segal bring their unique style to a spiritual masterpiece, celebrating the Sabbath as a day of rest, freedom, and renewal.

"Dror Yikra" was written by Dunash ben Labrat, a 10th-century poet and linguist who studied under Rabbi Sa'adia Ga'on. It is regarded as the first song written specifically for Shabbat, highlighting themes of spiritual redemption and the sacred bond between the people of Israel and the Sabbath.

The song reached new audiences through the historic performance by Shlomo Bar and the Natural Choice (Habreira Hativ‚Äôeet) more than 30 years ago. This adaptation featured a traditional Yemenite melody, bringing "Dror Yikra" into the cultural mainstream and reaffirming its place as a beloved part of Jewish heritage.

"Dror Yikra" reflects the Sabbath as a time for spiritual renewal and liberation‚Äîa foretaste of the world to come. Just as the Sabbath and the people of Israel protect one another, this sacred day offers freedom from routine and a connection to divine purpose.

Don‚Äôt forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more inspiring performances and timeless music!


#DrorYikra #ShabbatSongs #BarryAndBatyaSegal #JewishMusic #HebrewPoetry #Sabbath #spiritualredemption

videos.description:
This 17th-century Jewish poem (piyut), authored by Rabbi Sa'adya ben Amram, has endured as a cherished song across generations. 

Written in both Hebrew and Yemenite Arabic, this moving ballad reflects the deep relationship between the body and soul. 

It conveys the idea that the body doesn't constrain the soul's purpose, but rather complements it. By uniting body and spirit, we can truly fulfill our divine mission. 

Though the soul is familiar with the bliss of heaven, the body remains grounded on earth, where we glimpse paradise. When these two elements harmonize, peace is within reach.

Sapari ‚Äì Won‚Äôt You Tell
"Won‚Äôt you tell me, pure one,
Won‚Äôt you tell, and let us rejoice in Teiman (Yemen)."

The poem speaks of wisdom and royalty, asking where the beloved is. The dove replies that she is in faraway lands, her heart at sea, yet her spirit is draped in glory. The imagery of wandering through labyrinths and ivory chambers reflects a journey of spiritual awakening. The pure soul is called to rise from darkness and embrace the sacred union, resisting worldly temptations.


Barry and Batya Segal, co-founders of Vision for Israel, work to combat the growing poverty in Israel, spreading the love of Yeshua by addressing the physical and emotional needs of the people in practical ways. Learn more at Vision for Israel.

Sapari nagil ba‚Äôteima,
Sapari nagil ba‚Äôteima‚Ä¶

videos.title: Lecha Dodi | Barry and Batya Segal Music
videos.description:
Traditional Shabbat Liturgy. Music: Uri Shevach and Yosef Grin.

Discover the profound beauty of 'Lecha Dodi,' a cherished Jewish tradition that invites us to embrace the sanctity of Shabbat. 

The refrain, 'Let us go, my beloved, to greet the bride/the Sabbath presence, let us welcome,' echoes the heartfelt request of Israel's 'beloved' (God) to unite in welcoming the 'bride' (the Sabbath). 

This poetic composition, originating in the 16th century by Shlomo Halevi Alkabetz, draws inspiration from the Song of Songs and the Prophets, symbolizing the relationship between the Jewish people and God. 

Join us on a journey that culminates in a powerful call for Messianic deliverance and the celebration of the great Shabbat.

#jewishmusic 
#LechaDodi
#worship

videos.description:
Traditional Yemenite folk song. Lyrics: Rabbi Sa'adya ben Amram.

This 17th-century Jewish poem (piyut) was written by Rabbi Sa'adya ben Amram and has remained a beloved song throughout history. With both Hebrew and Yemenite Arabic, this beautiful ballad is an ode to the connection between body and soul. It is a testament to how the body and mind are one; our bodies do not limit our soul‚Äôs purpose, but rather support it. We must merge these parts of ourselves to fully serve our ultimate purpose. While our souls know the bliss of heaven, our bodies must remain on earth where we may only learn of paradise. When the two are in harmony, we can know peace.

This psalm is a celebration of God's constant and continued protection of His people. Though we may slumber and rest, our God is constantly vigilant and watching over us. We must trust Him as our protector, and rely on Him alone for our reassurance. Though worldly entities may seem tempting, the only stronghold that is always diligent is God's love.
